history.content: 70 is required to declare and the department wants you to take EECS 16A/B before 70, so they don't imagine many sophomore students who have declared CS but not taken EECS 16B.

children.subject: I wholeheartedly agree with the sentiment in this post. Personally I took Math 54 over 16B, and then I took 16B my last possible semester. I am glad I made that choice.

if they want this to be done, then why not make 16a/16b a prereq for 70? Even though prereqs are not enforced, i do not see why it isnt even listed... the only prereq is sophomore mathematical maturity which many will have gained by taking math1a/math1b freshman fall and math 1b/eecs16a freshman spring. If sophomore level math maturity (eecs16b) is required for 70, then students should be able to take eecs16b as a sophomore...

I think I had this same question last year when I was in your exact position, and I did not really get an answer; but the main reason I think that they are making it really difficult for declared, 3rd year, and 4th year students to get in is that they want students to take EE 16A and B as early as possible. I think EECS’ expectation is that students take 16A/B before taking CS 70, which is required in order to declare. I'm not positive but I think this might be why the instructors are allowing more undeclared students a spot, to encourage them to take it and not skip it and go straight to 70/declaring.

I don't think that intention is wrong since it comes from a pedagogical place of wanting to get students to take things in a specific order according to how they structure they courses, but I don't really agree with the way they choose to "enforce" it by not really making that a strict requirement and also applying pressure on undeclared L&S students to get a good grade in 61A/B/70. 

As a freshman, I dropped 16B and decided instead to focus on getting a good grade in 61B and 70 and declaring, and I think the rationale was sound and I was even advised to do this by peer mentors. I mean, really, if you can't even declare CS, then how will 16B help you? (Perhaps data science as an alternative, but ask many in the DS/ML route and they'll say 16A/B is still not enough lin. alg. preparation. and would say 54/110 is more effective since they are not trying to teach EE as well.) I think it has been well demonstrated by the hoards of students in your position and in mine, who are trying to get into 16B later on, that 16B is not necessary to do well in 70 and beyond.

I hope they do something about this system soon, since there are conflicting opinions currently on how a L&S CS student should go about their classes and that makes it confusing and stressful for a lot of us.  If faculty really believe that taking 16B is imperative before 70 and the UD courses, then this should be an enforced requirement in declaring. If it is not an enforced requirement, then students should not be punished by faculty/the department for not listening to their suggested course path. They are not enforcing the requirement, but, as you have shown, they are enforcing the punishment.

history.content: There are relatively few declared LSCS sophomores and there are many LSCS intended but undeclared sophomores who faculty would also like to take the course.

children.subject: op accounted for this in their post when they said most sophomores havent had phase1 yet...

Heads up that Berkeley Guide shows OPEN reserved seats. If you look at CS 194-35 as an example, it shows 4 reserved seats for CS/DataSci because there are 4 spots left in the class, but all 100 seats are actually restricted for students declared in those majors.

So for EE 16B it could be that because declared students tend to be older students (thus earlier Phase 1), more of those reserved spots for declared students might have already been filled.

history.content:
I'm a L&S declared sophomore majoring in CS, and I'm interested in taking EECS 16B next semester.

However, I found that for EECS 16B, L&S CS declared sophomores have much less reserved seats than L&S undeclared sophomores. I took this screenshot today, but since most sophomores haven't enrolled yet, I could assume that the number of reserved seats for sophomores is almost the same as 2 weeks ago.

The reason I declared as soon as finishing all pre-reqs is to have a better chance of enrolling in EECS and CS courses, and I believe that many of you did this for the same reason. So, having a lower chance of enrolling in EECS 16B after I declared doesn't really make sense to me. If this is the case, why don't I wait until the end of my sophomore year to declare...

I'm just wondering if this is really the case, or am I missing anything?
history.subject: For EECS 16B, why do L&S declared sophomores have less reserved seats than undeclared ones?
